title: Children in War Zones 1945-2025
description: Historical collection of images and descriptions of children affected by armed conflicts

wars.description: Some children, survivors of the Auschwitz concentration camp, emerge from their barracks shortly after liberation. Poland, after January 27, 1945 / On the 27th of January 1945, Auschwitz is liberated. Months later, WWII will end. Children were especially vulnerable to Nazi persecution.  As many as 1.5 million Jewish children alone were murdered or died at the hands of Nazi officials or their collaborators.

The Greek Civil War (1946-1949) created conditions whereby children were removed from their homes out of war zones and into neighbouring Eastern European countries. The result was that approximately 28,000 children crossed the borders in Eastern European countries during the course of the Civil War.

1950: A student in Suwon prepares to drink her daily ration of milk, provided by UNICEF ( UNICEF/UNI43171/Fowler Republic of Korea) / It is estimated over 100,000 Korean children were orphaned or displaced during the Korean War, separated from their parents by death, geography and poverty.
The Arab-Israeli conflict of 1967 created new waves of Palestinian refugees. Many children found themselves in refugee camps, where they would spend decades of their lives without a stable home.
wars.estimated_affected: The Six-Day War resulted in more than 15,000 Arab fatalities, while Israel suffered fewer than 1,000. No data on children fatalities

wars.description: Napalm Girl, June 8, 1972, Nick Ut / The picture captured the trauma and indiscriminate violence of a conflict that claimed, by some estimates, a million or more civilian lives. Officially titled “The Terror of War,” the photo is better known by the nickname given to the badly burned, naked 9-year-old at its center.
wars.estimated_affected: c.a. 84,000 war deaths among children (under age 15)
sources: Charles Hirschman, Samuel Preston, and Vu Manh Loi. 1995. “Vietnamese Casualties During the American War.” Population and Development Review 21: 783-812.

wars.description: Military use of children in iran-iraq war in iranian fronts, unknown date
wars.estimated_affected: 218,867 Iranians died due to war injuries. Civilians fatalities (mostly women and children) account for 15.3% (N=33,430) of total deaths. A major consequence of these deaths was that it left more than 144,000 children orphaned.

wars.description: Countless thousands of children were slaughtered during the Rwandan genocide. Proof of the carnage was everywhere throughout the country in the months after the killing. Children were often deliberately targeted for sexual violence, torture, persecution, forcible transfer, murder and extermination.

During the war, regime forces killed between 7,000–9,000 Kosovar Albanians,engaged in countless acts of rape,destroyed entire villages, and displaced nearly one million people. Many of the wartime rape surbivors were young girls, from 13 to 19 years old. Mostly rape were committed paramilitaries associated with Arkan (serbian warlord) group, where the majority of rapes are carried out in the presence of children and men who later were killed.
wars.estimated_affected: more than 1,000 children lost their lives during the conflict.

wars.description: Almost 33,000 children have been killed and maimed in Afghanistan over the past 20 years, an average of one child every five hours.
Average of at least 16 children killed or injured in Ukraine every week as escalation of war nears 1,000 days (2024).

At least 600,000 people - half of them children - have been displaced from Al Fasher and surrounding camps in recent months. Inside the city, an estimated 260,000 civilians, including 130,000 children, remain trapped in desperate conditions, cut off from aid for more than 16 months. More than 31,000 [children] have experienced gross violations of their rights – abducted, killed and raped.

20.000 children killed in 23 months of war- more than one child killed every hour.At least 42,011 children have been injured, according to the Ministry of Health, with the UN Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities reporting at least 21,000 children left permanently disabled. At least 132,000 children aged under five face risk of death from acute malnutrition.

metadata.notes: Estimates of affected children are approximate and based on multiple sources. Actual numbers could be significantly higher due to the difficulty of collecting accurate data during conflicts.
